speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.4: Student Code of Conduct - The board will review proposed updates to the district’s Student Code of Conduct, which outlines behavioral expectations and disciplinary procedures. Key changes include new rules around cell phone usage during instructional time, updates to the dress code to reflect inclusivity and professionalism, and revisions to disciplinary consequences to promote restorative practices.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thanks, Graham. I think it’d be helpful to hear from Ellen first—what do you see as the biggest challenge in getting kids to buy into this updated code?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, David. Ellen, maybe we could talk just briefly about what kind of outreach we’ve had to parents and students, because I suspect they’re not exactly sure what these changes mean.

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Kate. I think the biggest challenge is making sure students understand why these rules exist—not just that there’s a rule, but why it matters.  

Do any of us have examples of how we've explained the purpose behind cell phone use to middle or high schoolers?  

I know some principals have done cool things with student-led discussions. Maybe someone else tried something similar?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Ellen. I appreciate your framing.  

Maybe we could start by asking each principal to share one specific way they’ve helped students *understand* the “why” behind the cell phone policy?  

I’m curious—do you think those methods actually shifted behavior, or was it mostly awareness?  

And does anyone here have data showing whether those conversations improved compliance over time?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Judy. That’s a great idea—let’s hear from the principals on how they’ve framed the “why.”  
Do any of you have anecdotal evidence that talking through the reasons made a difference in student behavior?  
I wonder if we could track that across schools—maybe a quick survey after those sessions?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Hi, everybody. Sorry I missed the beginning of the conversation. Could we go back to the last question? And I think I'm going to repeat it again, because I don't want to miss anything. Judi asked the principals if they have anecdotes where talking through the "why" has changed behavior. Is that correct?

speaker: judyle
content:
Yes, Jon, that’s right—thank you for clarifying.
Could we get at least two principals to share an example of when explaining the “why” led to better student buy-in?
I’d love to hear how they structured those conversations—was it whole group, small groups, peer-led?
And did they notice differences in engagement or discipline referrals afterward?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
So, Judith, can I take a stab at answering that question? I guess I'll try to answer it for my school. But I'd like to say, I agree with everything that you said. It really makes sense to me. 

So, yes, I remember doing a presentation with my staff, and then we went out and talked to our eighth graders and seventh graders. And so, I didn't come up with it myself, but I liked the idea of using the analogy of, well, let's look at what happens when we're driving, okay, and you have your phone next to you, and then suddenly you need to reach down and grab it. You lose control of the vehicle. Okay, so we're trying to teach them that same thing. Like, if you're trying to learn something while looking at your phone, you're losing control of your brain. And then I saw the results of that. And I think it worked pretty well. 

So I thought that was a good way to explain it.

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Katrina. That analogy really resonated—I’ll bet many students connected with that.
Did you get feedback from students afterward? Did anyone say, “Oh, now I get it,” or “I used to do that, but I won’t anymore”?  
And were there any noticeable shifts in classroom distractions or referrals following that session?

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Katrina, I appreciate that story—it’s powerful.  
How did you gauge whether students truly internalized the message beyond just nodding along?  
I wonder if a brief follow-up survey or check-in might help measure long-term impact.  
Would you consider piloting that in your school next year?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Well, I am definitely willing to pilot it. I think it's worth checking out. Honestly, though, it felt like the majority of the students responded positively. They got it. It wasn't necessarily like, oh, I'm never touching my phone again. It was more like, oh, I see why that's important. I think it's a big shift.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Well, I think it sounds very effective. I wonder if we could, perhaps, have the principals report back to us at the end of the year on how successful they found the programs to be. Do we already have that information? Or should we ask for it?

speaker: judyle
content:
Thanks, Kate. I agree—we should collect that info.
Can we please ask each principal to include a brief reflection on student buy-in and behavioral change in their annual report?
And maybe add a simple survey item: “After today’s lesson, do you feel more prepared to make responsible choices about phones?”
Let’s keep tracking that.

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thanks, Kate. I think that’s a solid plan—simple but meaningful.
Judie, do you mind assigning one person to coordinate collecting those reflections and surveys from the principals?
Also, I wonder if we could pair that with a teacher feedback loop—after all, they’re the ones seeing the behaviors daily.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you, Ellen. One other question. When we talk about this, I would hope that most of us will have a discussion with our kids before we implement this. I'm assuming that's true. But I do have a couple of questions. How much of this are we doing through social media announcements? And how much of it are we doing directly with the students? Because I think there's been times in the past when it seemed like some of the announcements were sent out via social media and the students weren't aware of them. Am I wrong about that?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, no, I think that's totally fair. I mean, I know that I've seen emails go out to parents and I haven't seen them posted anywhere else. And I know sometimes it feels like things are getting lost. So I'm glad you brought that up.

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Jon, I think you raise a valid point—communication channels matter.
Maybe we should clarify which platforms we use for different messages.
Would someone please confirm: Are we relying too heavily on email and social media instead of direct classroom delivery?
We should ensure consistency between home and school messaging.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content:
I think that's great. Thank you, David. Let me just give a little bit of background here. There was a time when I had a situation happen with a student and I told her to send me a text. She looked at me kind of funny and she said, "Well, Mr. Alcaro, I don't have a cell phone." And I was stunned. And I said, "What?" And she said, "I don't have a cell phone." And I couldn't believe it. And I said, "Why not?" And she said, "Because I don't need it. My mom doesn't allow it."
And I was thinking to myself, wow, what a difference that is. And I was sitting there saying to myself, geez, I don't know how many times I've had a kid call me after hours or whatever. And I thought, boy, that's a lot of pressure for a parent to put on a child. And I certainly understand that there are reasons for these devices. But I just wanted to throw that out there. I don't know. Anybody else have thoughts on that?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Well, I think that raises an interesting point, Jon. I think we want to be sensitive to the fact that not everyone has a device, nor does everyone want one. I suppose we could find ways to encourage, but I'd hate to penalize those who don't have them. Maybe we could work together to figure out how to deal with that.

speaker: judyle
content:
Jon, thank you for sharing that experience—that moment really struck me.
I wonder if we’ve considered offering alternative ways to communicate with families who don’t rely on texts or apps.
Could we please assign someone to review communication methods across departments and recommend low-tech options where possible?
And let’s make sure those recommendations reflect real-life access—not just assumptions.

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
That’s such a thoughtful point, Jon. I’m glad you shared that story.  
Judie, could you please look into how many families actually receive communications via text or app?  
And while you're at it, can we identify which families might be left out due to lack of access?  
I’d like to make sure we’re not creating unintended barriers.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Okay, well, thank you. I appreciate that. And thank you, Ellen, for taking care of that because I think that's going to be a good thing.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, I guess I'm wondering though, like, so I don't know, is there anything we can do to help with that? Like, I don't know. Is there something that the district could offer?

speaker: davidoberg
content:
Katriona, I hear your concern—and I think it's important we acknowledge disparities without overreacting.
Do we have data on how many families lack reliable access to smartphones or internet?
If not, could someone please pull that info by next month?
And then, yes—let’s explore whether affordable options exist, or even pilot a program to provide basic devices to those in need.
But let’s move carefully—I don’t want to assume need without evidence.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Well, David, I would say that we already have some very limited resources available to some extent. For instance, the technology department has some laptops, and I know that the transportation department has some buses with wi-fi. But I think perhaps we could take a look at that.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.4: Should the board adopt the revised Student Code of Conduct, including updates to cell phone policies, dress code, and discipline procedures?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: davidoberg
content: yes

speaker: kateacuff
content: abstain

speaker: judyle
content: abstain

speaker: ellenosborne
content: abstain

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Yes, I agree with that. It makes sense to me.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: no

speaker: grahampaige
content: I am concerned about how this new policy may affect students who do not have access to smart phones. This could create inequities among our students. Also, I am worried about privacy issues related to recording student conversations. The potential negative consequences outweigh any benefits to me. So my vote is no.
